facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 94 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 94 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 24, 1964 of Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 208 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 94 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 24, 1964 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 208 of 1964.

facts.text: High Court of Assam and Nagaland passed judgment dated January 24, 1964 in Civil Rule No. 208 of 1964 under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment and order of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland dated January 24, 1964 passed in Civil Rule No. 208 of 1964 under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Biswabahan Das was lessee of the excise shop from 1956 to 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The facts necessary for the disposal of this appeal are as follows. One Biswabahan Das, the appellant before us, was the lessee of the said shop from 1956 to 1962.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner settled the shop with Biswabahan Das for 1962-64.

anchor.surface_text: The shop was settled with him again for the term 1962-64 by the Deputy Commissioner. On appeal to the Board of Revenue, this was set aside,

facts.text: Board of Revenue set aside the 1962-64 settlement with Biswabahan Das on basis of report by Inspector of Excise and settled shop with respondent Hazarika.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Board of Revenue, this was set aside, on the basis of a report submitted by the Inspector of Excise and the shop was settled with the present respondent.

facts.text: Biswabahan Das filed writ petition in Assam High Court and succeeded on ground that evidence of Inspector taken behind his back.

anchor.surface_text: Biswabahan went to the Assam High Court with a writ petition and succeeded there on the ground that the evidence of the Inspector had been taken behind his back

facts.text: High Court held no useful purpose in granting relief to Biswabahan as licence period about to expire.

anchor.surface_text: and as such should not have been taken into consideration, but the High Court also held in that matter that nouseful purpose would be served by granting any relief to Biswabahan at that late stage

facts.text: Hazarika remained lessee when fresh settlement became due.

anchor.surface_text: when the period of the licence was about to expire. This had the result that Hazarika remained the lessee of the shop when a fresh settlement became due.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner settled shop with Hazarika for 1964-1967.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner settled the shop with Hazarika again for the years 1964 to 1967. This settlement was challenged in appeal before the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: Settlement with Hazarika challenged in appeal before Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: This settlement was challenged in appeal before the Board of Revenue. The Board went into the question as to whether Hazarika was a suitable person

facts.text: Hazarika, as holder of firewood mahal licence, compounded offence of illegally felling green trees by paying Rs. 50 while acting as forest contractor.

anchor.surface_text: because as the holder of a firewood mahal licence he had compounded an offence of illegally felling green trees by paying Rs. 50 when he was acting as a forest contractor.

facts.text: Forest Beat Officer of Dibru Reserve detected Hazarika illegally felled green trees and converted to firewood, though entitled only to dead and fallen trees.

anchor.surface_text: From the appellate order of the Board of Revenue which was .quashed by the High Court, it appears that a Forest Beat Officer of Dibru Reserve had detected that Hazarika had illegally felled some green trees

facts.text: No dispute that Hazarika paid compensation of Rs. 50 for the forest offence.

anchor.surface_text: There was nodispute that Hazarika had paid compensation of Rs. 50 in respect thereof and had filed an affidavit before the Board of Revenue

facts.text: Hazarika filed affidavit before Board of Revenue that mistake committed by labourers in collecting broken and fallen green trees in his absence.

anchor.surface_text: that a mistake had been committed by his labourers in collecting some broken and fallen green trees in his absence. The Board was not satisfied with this explanation

facts.text: Board of Revenue not satisfied with Hazarika's explanation and considered his conduct unsuitable for excise shop settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The Board was not satisfied with this explanation and took the view that the fact of Hazarika having compounded the offence did not clear his conduct although he had succeeded in getting a sub- sequent settlement of a forest mahal.

facts.text: Board of Revenue set aside settlement with Hazarika considering his conduct.

anchor.surface_text: In view of his conduct as discussed above we do not consider respondent Hazarika to be a suitable candidate and are unable to uphold the settlement made with him.

facts.text: High Court quashed Board of Revenue's order relying on s.345(6) CrPC, holding compounding effect of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on s. 345 6 of the Criminal. Procedure Code to reach the conclusion that the compounding of the offence had the effect of an acquittal

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.345(6) CrPC not applicable to offence under Assam Forest Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: Before us Mr. Sarjoo Prasad appearing in support of the appeal contended that s. 345 6 of the Criminal Procedure Code had noapplication to an offence under the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891.

facts.text: Compounding under s.62 Assam Forest Regulation does not have effect of acquittal or clear character.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. 2 of s. 62 only protects him with regard to further proceedings, but has not the effect of clearing his character or vindicating his conduct.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, restored Board of Revenue order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and that of the Board of Revenue is restored.

facts.text: Hazarika got subsequent settlement of forest mahal after compounding.

anchor.surface_text: although he had succeeded in getting a sub- sequent settlement of a forest mahal.

under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India. The sole question involved in this appeal is whether the High Court was right in quashing the order of the Board of Revenue on the ground that the very basis on which the appellate order of the Board was founded did number exist and that the Board had gone wrong in taking into companysideration the companypounding of an offence under the Forest Regulation by the petitioner before the High Court as affecting his suitability in getting settlement of an excise shop in Dibrugarh area.

anchor.surface_text: Section 62 sub-s.  1  of the said Regulation which has the marginal numbere power to companypound offences provides- The State Government may, by numberification in the official Gazette, empower a Forest Officer by name, or as holding an office,-  a  to accept from any person against whom a reasonable suspicion exists that he has companymitted any forest offence, other than an offence specified in section 58 or section 59, a sum of money by way of companypensation for the offence which such, person is suspected to have companymitted and  b  when any property has been seized as liable to companyfiscation, to release the same on payment of the value thereof as estimated by such officer. Sub-section  2  provides- On the payment of such sum of money, or such value, or both, as the case may be, to such officer, the suspected person, if in custody, shall be discharged, the property, if any, seized shall be released and numberfurther proceedings shall be taken against such person or property.

arguments.claim: s.345(6) CrPC has no application to offence under Assam Forest Regulation

anchor.surface_text: Before us Mr. Sarjoo Prasad appearing in support of the appeal contended that s. 345(6) of the Criminal Procedure Code had no application to an offence under the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891.

arguments.court_reasoning: Offence not specified under s.345(1) or (2)

arguments.claim: Principle of s.345(6) limited to specified offences; cannot extend to other Acts without similar provision

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by Mr. Sarjoo Prasad that assuming the effect of an acquittal to be the wiping out or negation of the wrongful conduct on the part of the accused, the scope of sub-s. (6) was only limited to the offences specified in sub-ss. (1) and (2) of s. 345 and the principle thereof could not be extended to offences under other Acts unless there was a provision similar to sub-s. (6) in those Acts.

(2) of s. 62 was the same as that contained in s. 345(6) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.court_reasoning: No express acquittal; payment accepts suspicion without vindication

arguments.claim: Compounding under s.62 accepts truth of charge, does not clear character or vindicate conduct

anchor.surface_text: In effect the payment of compensation amounts to his acceptance of the truth of the charge against him. Sub-s. (2) of s. 62 only protects him with regard to further proceedings, but has not the effect of clearing his character or vindicating his conduct.

arguments.claim: Effect of compounding depends on law; unless expressly acquittal, no removal of stigma

anchor.surface_text: If the effect of composition is to amount to an acquittal then it may be said that no stigma should attach to the character of the person, but unless that is expressly provided for the mere rendering of compensation would not amount to the vindication of the character of the person charged with the offence.

arguments.claim: Appellate authorities have co-extensive powers with primary settling authority

anchor.surface_text: the powers of the Appellate Authorities in the matter of settlement would be coextensive with the powers of the primary authority, namely, the District Collector or the Sub-Divisional Officer. The same can be said of the powers of the Board of Revenue in this case.

arguments.claim: Certiorari lies only for jurisdictional error or error of law apparent on face of record, not every error

anchor.surface_text: one of the grounds on which the jurisdiction of the High Court on certiorari may be invoked, is an error of law apparent on the face of the record and not every error either of law or fact, which can be corrected by a superior court, in exercise of its statutory powers as a court of appeal or revision.

arguments.claim: Board did not exceed jurisdiction or commit apparent error by considering conduct

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Board of Revenue had not gone wrong in law in taking into consideration Hazarika's conduct in rendering compensation for a forest offence. The Board was quite competent to take the view that Hazarika was not vigilant in observing the law even if it had found-that it did not-that Hazarika's explanation was not unconvincing.

holdings.text: Section 345(6) of the CrPC has no application to an offence under the Assam Forest Regulation as the forest offence is not one specified under sub-sections (1) or (2) of Section 345.

anchor.surface_text: Section 345 1  of the Code prescribes that the offences thereunder specified may be compounded by the persons mentioned in the third column of the appended Table. By subs.  2  provision is made for the compounding of the offences specified in the first column of the Table appended to this sub-section by certain persons with the permission of the court before which any prosecution for the offence is pending. Sub-s.  6  lays down that-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading limits s.345(6) effect of acquittal to offences listed in sub-ss.(1) and (2); forest offences not included.

holdings.text: Compounding under s.62(2) of the Assam Forest Regulation only protects from further proceedings and does not clear character or vindicate conduct.

anchor.surface_text: In effect the payment of compensation amounts to his acceptance of the truth of the charge against him. Sub-s.  2  of s. 62 only protects him with regard to further proceedings, but has not the effect of clearing his character or vindicating his conduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.62 empowers acceptance of compensation upon suspicion, payment discharges from custody and bars proceedings but lacks provision for acquittal or character vindication unlike CrPC.

holdings.text: The effect of compounding an offence depends on the specific statutory provision; unless expressly stated as acquittal, it does not remove stigma from character.

anchor.surface_text: If the effect of composition is to amount to an acquittal then it may be said that no stigma should attach to the character of the person, but unless that is expressly provided for the mere rendering of compensation would not amount to the vindication of the character of the person charged with the offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes statutes with explicit acquittal effect from those without, rejecting analogy to CrPC for Forest Regulation.

holdings.text: The High Court was not right in holding that compounding under s.62 Assam Forest Regulation equivalent to acquittal under s.345(6) CrPC, involving no moral turpitude.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, was not right in coming to the conclusion that the effect of s. 62 of the Assam Regulation was the same as that of s. 345 6  of the Criminal Procedure Code and that no moral turpitude of any description could be said to be involved in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court misapplied CrPC to Forest Regulation; compounding does not negate conduct for suitability assessment.

holdings.text: Powers of appellate authorities like Board of Revenue in settlement matters are co-extensive with primary settling authority.

anchor.surface_text: the powers of the Appellate Authorities in the matter of settlement would be coextensive with the powers of the primary authority, namely, the District Collector of the Sub-Divisional Officer. The same can be said of the powers of the Board of Revenue in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Nagendra Nath Bora, appellate powers match primary authority including considering moral character under Executive Instruction III.

holdings.text: Board of Revenue did not exceed jurisdiction or commit error of law apparent on face of record by considering respondent's compounded forest offence for suitability.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Board of Revenue had not gone wrong in law in taking into consideration Hazarika's conduct in rendering compensation for a forest offence. The Board was quite competent to take the view that Hazarika was not vigilant in observing the law even if it had found-that it did not-that Hazarika's explanation was not unconvincing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board acted within co-extensive powers; consideration of conduct post-compounding not jurisdictional error or apparent legal mistake per certiorari standards.

holdings.text: High Court not justified in issuing certiorari under Art.226 to quash Board of Revenue's order.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 226 of the Constitution. In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and that of the Board of Revenue is restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No excess of jurisdiction or error apparent on record; writ not substitute for appeal.

precedents.citation: Chandanmal v. Rupakula Ramkrishnayya and another 1 ... A.I.R. 1942 Mad. 173 at 176

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to the observations of the Madras High Court in Chandanmal v. Rupakula Ramkrishnayya and another 1  that an agreement to companypound an offence under s. 345 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code was number in violation of any law or public policy.

precedents.case_name: Chandanmal v. Rupakula Ramkrishnayya and another
precedents.cited_proposition: an agreement to compound an offence under s. 345(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code was not in violation of any law or public policy

precedents.citation: Reg. v. Rahimat 2 ... I.L.R. 1 Bom. 147 at p. 151

anchor.surface_text: We were also referred to certain general observations in the case of Reg. v. Rahimat 2  that there was a class of cases which might be the subject either of criminal or civil companynizance and if the person injured desired to obtain companypensation the law did number forbid him whereas if he invoked the penal interposition of the Magistrate, that interposition was number refused.

precedents.cited_proposition: there was a class of cases which might be the subject either of criminal or civil cognizance and if the person injured desired to obtain compensation the law did not forbid him whereas if he invoked the penal interposition of the Magistrate, that interposition was not refused

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Bora and another v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam and others 1 ... 1958 S.C.R. 1240

anchor.surface_text: In Nagendra Nath Bora and another v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam and others 1  the Assam High Court had quashed certain orders of settlement of a number of companyntry spirit shops made by the Commissioner of the Hills Division and Appeals setting aside the orders of the Deputy Commissioner and the Excise Commissioner.

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Bora and another v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam and others
precedents.cited_proposition: powers of the Appellate Authorities in the matter of settlement would be co-extensive with the powers of the primary authority; jurisdiction of High Court under certiorari for error of law apparent on the face of the record, not every error, not substitute for appeal
precedents.cited_holding: There is no doubt that if the Appellate Authority whose duty it is to determine questions affecting the right to settlement of a liquor shop, in a judicial or quasi-judicial manner, acts in excess of its authority vested by law... its order is subject to the controlling authority of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and that of the Board of Revenue is restored.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; Board of Revenue order restored

order of the Board of Revenue is restored

anchor.surface_text: Section 345 1  of the Code prescribes that the offences thereunder specified may be compounded by the persons mentioned in the third column of the appended Table. By subs.  2  provision is made for the compounding of the offences specified in the first column of the Table appended to this sub-section by certain persons with the permission of the court before which any prosecution for the offence is pending. Sub-s.  6  lays down that-
